subject: Constructor in Player.h
content: I keep getting this error that says that SimplePlayer has not been declared or that a type-specifier is expected before I return a new SimplePlayer, and I was kind of confused as to what that is about. . For reference that is the error that I am getting, and also my constructor for SimplePlayer does not include another constructor for the Player class, like so. The reason it doesn't include one was because I couldn't find a constructor for the Player class to actually put in my subclass, and I'm assuming that this is what is keeping my code from compiling. I also tried adding Player() in the subclass constructor, but that said that a cast to public class Player is not allowed. So I'm confused on how we're supposed to include the constructor for the super class, and also how to fix the error that I get when trying to compile..
i_answer: . The reason it doesn't include one was because I couldn't find a constructor for the Player class to actually put in my subclass, and I'm assuming that this is what is keeping my code from compiling. I also tried adding Player() in the subclass constructor, but that said that a cast to public class Player is not allowed. So I'm confused on how we're supposed to include the constructor for the super class, and also how to fix the error that I get when trying to compile.. . You won't need a constructor for the superclass. Player is an abstract class that you would never make an instance of, instead, you make Simple and Human players. C++ by default will have an implicit constructor for the super class (super class is a Java term in C++ it is usually called the parent class). The subclass (again a java term, equivalently in C++ called child class) will inherit that constructor but as you can imagine, it is not enough. Simple player has a name that has to be initialized so you will need a custom constructor.. . . I keep getting this error that says that SimplePlayer has not been declared or that a type-specifier is expected before I return a new SimplePlayer, and I was kind of confused as to what that is about. .  For the type-specifier issue, remember two things. To have a semicolon at the end of SimplePlayer Class definition and also remember to #include "Player.h". . . class SimplePlayer : public Player {. public:. 	// stuff here. private:. 	// stuff here. }; // semicolon here

subject: [Card.cpp] Why is suit considered when comparing cards?
content: In the project spec, it says that we should first compare the rank of the card and if cards are the same rank, we then compare by suit. Why do we do this? Aren’t cards of the different suits (excluding trump/lead suit) considered equal in euchre?If I were to play an 8 of spades and another player plays an 8 of hearts (if lead/trump suit aren’t hearts or spades), wouldn’t our cards be equal in the eyes of the game?Maybe this is sorted out later but to me it seems like it would just cause confusion and possible errors with implementing gameplay.
i_answer: The portion of the spec you're talking about lays out three different contexts in which to compare cards. The simple case is when cards are ordered by rank (A > K > Q > J > 10 > 9), with ties broken by suit (D > C > H > S), you can think of the simple case as basic card rules. This is the logic that you will want to apply in the overloaded operators. Considering the trump suit and led suit will come into play in different functions and files.. . Think about card.cpp as a more general card file with a few euchre-specific functions. For example, we could use this to implement a different card game.

subject: Card_less() implementation question
content: Is there a better way of writing this function other than like a LOT of if and else if statements?. .
i_answer: Yes and no. There will be a good amount of if statements, but you can write this function without using else if/else or any nesting. A lot of the logic and cases can be implicit. Think about all of the different instances of two cards being compared and try to lay these out in a way where you consider the highest-value card first. Then, see what is true about the cards if they don't enter an if statement.

subject: get_suit(Suit trump)
content: Do we return the left bower here or is trump THE suit of the left bower. I am confused over the wording of the hint :/
i_answer: I think you return the suit of the given card, and if the given card is the left bower, then return the trump suit, because the left bower is considered to be in the trump suit.

subject: get_suit(suit trump) const quesiton
content: the hint in the RME says that the left bower is the trump suit.. . Does this mean that I will have to return both colors?. . For example, if the trump suit is diamonds, I have to return both diamonds and hearts?
i_answer: You're sort of on the right track; however, you will only return a single suit in this function (either the suit of the card, or the trump suit if you card is a left bower).

subject: Am I allowed to modify the stuff in Card.h

i_answer: For clarification, all of your implementation for Card should be in Card.cpp and you should not modify any .h files. Be sure to use the scope resolution operator for implementing member functions of the card class.

i_answer: You can only use the const keyword on member functions. You might have forgotten a "Card::" before the name of your function.

subject: Card.cpp operator overloading
content: For the operator overloading functions in Card.cpp, when it says "Returns true if lhs is higher value than rhs or the same card as rhs," are we supposed to compare the ranks and the suits of each card to the other?
i_answer: I believe that it should compare the cards according to Euchre rules. Thus, it should compare both the ranks and the suits of each card.

subject: Operator == overloading
content: What is the point of overloading == when we can use the same operator to compare objects directly?
i_answer: You can only use the == operator to compare objects directly if they are predefined types (say integers or characters). For types you construct yourself, you would need to overload the == operator to give it any meaning for that type. For example, you can use the == operator for strings because the string class defines an == operator which checks if each character of the string is the same.

subject: Euchre rules
content: A couple of questions regarding euchre:. . Why is there ranks 2-8 in the Card class when those cards are not played in euchre? . . What are the rankings of the jacks that are not left or right bower?(lower than queen but higher than 10 I assume). . What is the utility in the ==, <=, >= operators? Pretty sure that you can't have the same value of card since there are no duplicates, unless I am wrong about that..
i_answer: As always, if you're reading ahead then don't put in too much work before the project is officially released -- the spec is liable to change. To briefly answer your questions:. . 1. It's to have a "complete" card class -- you're right you don't need to use them for euchre. . . 2. Correct.. . 3. Similar to 1. Your understanding is correct, you shouldn't have duplicates in euchre.
